ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were in-person lectures twice a week and a discussion section once a week.
Weekly sections with a seminar format
live lecture also recorded
We also had weekly sections on Zoom, where we discussed the material and formulated analyses and arguments.
Virtual Discussion Section

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I got a great understanding of Russian history which I knew absolutely nothing about before this course.
Broad overview of the history of the Russian state, from the early days of Kievan Rus' to the 18th century Russian empire
I learned about the history of Russia from the 9th century to the 1800s. We learned about the rulers, culture, and religion through primary and secondary source readings.
Learned a lot about Russian history

This course helped me develop an understanding of Russian history, and also better understand how to formulate historical analysis. I learned how to analyze primary sources and extract relevant information to support analytical arguments.

I developed my ability to write timed essays and learned how to focus more deeply on one aspect of history in order to gain a richer  analysis. I also learned a bit more about the patterns which define and guide Russian history specifically and how history as a discipline is the study of interpretation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the information taught in this class was super interesting. However, the lectures were a little on the dry side.

The course was very good overall. Although it was online, I found that Professor Bushkovitch was an engaging and clear lecturer. The sections really helped to clarify things and ensure that we kept up with the material.
strength: Professor Bushkovitch and Emily were very accommodating and worked hard to make the course engaging via zoom.

This course was really well done! The lectures were interesting and comprehensive, and the sections were helpful to process the material and actively engage with it. Perhaps a little more active engagement in lecture wouldn't have hurt, but the main thing was learning from Professor Bushkovitch's wealth of knowledge, so the lecture style was definitely the right one.

There are no intrinsic weakness in this course. It is simply that lecture courses as whole dont engage me intellectually on the same level as a seminar, and that effect is increased when the whole course is online. The discussion sections were fruitful and the lectures were informative but easy to digest.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think as far as covid goes this class adapted well, though it was always a little funny to watch Professor Bushkovitch try to share his screen.
The class was pretty straightforwardly a live online lecture. Its format was therefore pretty simple, but I genuinely felt that it worked well.
The lectures and discussion sections succeeded.
All I can say is that I was more engaged in discussion sections simply because they called for more interaction. I would not know how to improve engagement in the lecture portion of this course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are really interested in Russian history then definitely take this course.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in Russian history before the Revolution.
Yes, this was a fun history course where I learned a lot!

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in Russian history! It was a great and thorough introduction to the subject, and Professor Bushkovitch is a walking talking wealth of information, and was fascinating to learn from.

I would, depending on what the student desires. For me, this was generally a low-stress, low-workload course with fascinating and unique readings which open the door to new historical material not often covered in general history courses.

extras.title:
HIST 290 01/RSEE 225 01
        Russia from the 9th C to 1801
